title-group.article-title: Testing Moderating Hypotheses in Limited Dependent Variable and Other Nonlinear Models
title-group.subtitle: Secondary Versus Total Interactions

author-notes.corresp: Harry P. Bowen, McColl School of Business, Queens University of Charlotte, 1900 Selwyn Avenue, Charlotte, NC 28274, USA E-mail: bowenh@queens.edu

abstract.p: The use of limited dependent variable (LDV) models is becoming ubiquitous in empirical management research. When using such models, researchers frequently postulate and test that the relationship between an explanatory variable and the dependent variable is moderated by another variable by including in the model an interaction variable. Although recent papers clarify methods for analyzing a moderating effect in LDV models, it is not widely appreciated that this effect confounds two moderating effects: one associated with including an interaction variable in the model and one associated with the inherent nonlinearity of such models. This article presents a method to separate these two sources of a moderating effect for a general class of nonlinear models that includes all LDV models commonly used in the management literature. For such models, the article demonstrates that the statistically correct method to assess the validity of a moderating hypothesis is not, as currently recommended, to test for significance of the total moderating effect derived from the model that includes the interaction variable but instead to test for significance of the secondary moderating effect, the latter defined as the difference between two moderating effects: the one in the model that includes the interaction variable and the one in the model that excludes this variable. The result that the secondary effect is the correct statistic for testing a moderating hypothesis is very general, and it applies whenever a moderating hypothesis is to be tested by including an interaction variable in any model, whether linear or nonlinear.

body.p: The use of discrete limited dependent variable (LDV) models such as logit is becoming ubiquitous in empirical management research (Hoetker, 2007). When using such models, researchers frequently hypothesize that the relationship between one explanatory variable and the dependent variable depends on the values of another variable by including in their models an interaction variable. In an influential article, Ai and Norton (2003) argued that for such models the common practice of testing a moderating hypothesis on the basis of the sign and significance of the coefficient on the interaction variable is incorrect since this coefficient does not equal the analytically correct moderating effect in such models.1 Due to the importance of moderating hypotheses in empirical management research, recent articles have sought to inform management researchers of the issues raised by Ai and Norton and have elaborated on methods to analyze and interpret the analytically correct moderating effect in LDV models (e.g., Hoetker, 2007; Wiersema & Bowen, 2009; Zelner, 2009). This research stream highlights that the analysis of moderating effects in LDV models is both subtle and complex, a fact that has even led some researchers to eschew the use of LDV models to investigate their moderating hypotheses.2 Most important, this research suggests that many past studies that have tested for moderating effects in LDV models may have done so incorrectly.

While recent papers demonstrate the proper derivation of the analytically correct moderating effect in an LDV model that includes an interaction variable, it is not widely understood or appreciated that this moderating effect confounds two distinct moderating effects: a structural effect that arises naturally from the inherent nonlinearity of any LDV model and a secondary effect that arises from including an interaction variable in the model. This confounding has important implications for researchers who seek to test a moderating hypothesis by including an interaction variable in an LDV model since it means that an analysis of the analytically correct moderating effect may not identify the nature and significance of the secondary moderating effect associated with including the interaction variable in a model. In particular, a significant analytically correct moderating effect may only reflect inherent structural characteristics of the particular LDV model used. Conversely, lack of significance of the analytically correct moderating effect may mask a statistically significant secondary moderating effect and hence mask that the substantive moderating hypothesis underlying the introduction of an interaction variable in a model is in fact valid. That the analytically correct moderating effect in an LDV model can contain both structural and secondary components means that, at a minimum, researchers who postulate a moderating hypothesis when using such models need to more clearly articulate which moderating effect is to be the focus of their analysis. In this regard, this article argues that while the analytically correct moderating effect can be of interest, it is the secondary moderating effect that is the proper focus of an analysis that seeks to formulate and test a moderating hypothesis by including an interaction variable in an LDV model.

This article contributes to the recent stream of literature (e.g., Ai & Norton, 2003; Hoetker, 2007) that has addressed the analysis and interpretation of moderating effects in LDV models by delving more deeply into the nature of these effects. In doing so, I extend Ai and Norton’s results for logit and probit models to a general class of nonlinear models that includes all LDV models commonly used in the management literature as well as, for example, models for count data such as the negative binomial model and hybrid models such as the tobit. For this general class of models, I demonstrate that introducing an interaction variable in a model derives fundamentally from the substantive moderating hypothesis of a linear and deterministic relationship between the moderator variable and the population coefficient on the explanatory variable whose relationship with the dependent variable is being moderated, and that a proper test of this substantive moderating hypothesis is to test for significance of the estimated coefficient on the interaction variable. I then demonstrate that, contrary to Ai and Norton, the correct test statistic for assessing the nature and significance of the moderating effect that arises from this substantive moderating hypothesis is not the analytically correct moderating effect but is instead the secondary moderating effect, the latter defined as the difference between two moderating effects: that arising in the model that includes the interaction variable and that arising in the model that excludes the interaction variable. This result emphasizes that the moderating effect of interest when including an interaction variable in a model is one that indicates the contribution to an existing moderating effect, and not the moderating effect that exists in the model that includes the interaction variable. This means that, for example, one can support the hypothesis of a positive moderating effect when including an interaction variable in a model even if the analytically correct moderating effect is negative. This seemingly paradoxical statement follows from a deeper consideration of the substantive moderating hypothesis that gives rise to including an interaction variable in a model.

Given the importance of the secondary moderating effect, I propose in this article a method to decompose the analytically correct moderating effect that arises in any model that includes an interaction variable into its structural and secondary components. This decomposition allows the researcher to identify and test for the nature of the secondary moderating effect, and it also permits the researcher to gain an understanding of the analytically correct moderating effect by examining how its value relates to the values of its underlying structural and secondary components.

Following the development of the proposed decomposition, I investigate theoretically its implications for the binary logit model. This model is the most widely used discrete LDV model in the management literature (Hoetker, 2007), and it has been the focus of most current research on methods for analyzing and interpreting the results from LDV models (Ai & Norton, 2003; Bowen & Wiersema, 2004; Hoetker, 2007; Wiersema & Bowen, 2009; Zelner, 2009). I then present a numerical example using the binary logit model to illustrate the proposed decomposition and the methods to analyze the results obtained. Finally, to encourage and enable researchers to test their moderating hypotheses using the secondary moderating effect, Appendix A provides the Stata commands used to perform the analyses conducted in the numerical example, while Appendix B presents the general formulas for the total, structural, and secondary moderating effects that arise in the general class of nonlinear models considered in this article when the focus and moderating variables are variously continuous or discrete.

sec.title: Moderating Effects and Interaction Variables
sec.p: To provide a foundation for the methods proposed in this article, it is useful to first lay out some terminology. I define a moderating effect to be the effect that a change in one variable—the moderator variable—has on the relationship between another model variable—the focus variable—and the dependent variable. This relationship between the focus and dependent variables is commonly called the “marginal effect” of the focus variable (e.g., Bowen & Wiersema, 2004). In general, a marginal effect measures the effect on the dependent variable of a change in an explanatory variable, and it therefore indicates the nature of the relationship between the explanatory variable and the dependent variable. In the analysis to follow, I assume that the focus and moderator variables are continuous variables and hence, as in Ai and Norton (2003), that the moderating effect in a given model can be computed as the cross-partial derivative of the conditional expectation of the dependent variable, first with respect to the focus variable and then with respect to the moderator variable.3 Finally, I define an interaction variable to be the variable formed by multiplying at each observation the value of the focus variable times the value of the moderator variable. While an interaction variable is a well understood construct, my analysis generalizes the notion of an interaction variable to the case where the focus variable and moderator variable, and any other model variable, can be a function its native value (e.g., when a model variable is measured as the logarithm of its value).

Given the preceding definitions, I now proceed from the simple to the general to lay out the notion of a moderating effect as commonly employed in applied statistical work. Consider first the standard linear regression model for which the population relationship between a dependent variable Y and a set of (K + 1) explanatory variables (X0, X1, . . . , XK) is assumed to be linear. This population relationship can be written:

In this expression, X0 = 1 so β0 is the intercept term. As will be made explicit throughout this article, the substantive moderating hypothesis underlying the introduction of an interaction variable in a model is the hypothesis that the population coefficient on the focus variable varies with the value of the moderator variable. The moderator variable can be either included or excluded from the assumed population relationship.

Without loss of generality, let X1 be the focus variable, let X2 be the hypothesized moderator variable, and assume that variable X2 is included as a model variable. Given this, the hypothesis that moderator variable X2 moderates the population relationship between focus variable X1 and dependent variable Y can be stated as the hypothesis that there is a linear and deterministic relationship between moderator variable X2 and the population coefficient β1 on the focus variable:

This expression states that the value of the population coefficient β1 equals a constant value plus a constant coefficient βM times the value of moderator variable X2. Expression 2 is deterministic in that no error term is included on the right-hand side of this expression. If an error term were included, the implied model would be one form of a “random coefficients model” (e.g., Greene, 2008), or more generally, one form of the general class of hierarchical linear models (e.g., Radenburg & Byrk, 2002), and it would require dealing with issues regarding the relationship between the error term one attaches to Expression 2 and the error term one attaches to the population relationship given by Expression 1. Virtually all applications that use an interaction variable assume, if only implicitly, the substantive moderating hypothesis given by Expression 2. This assumption is maintained throughout this article.
Inserting Expression 2 for β1 into Expression 1 produces a linear model that includes the interaction variable X1 X2:

Given this expression, the validity of the substantive moderating hypothesis given by Expression 2 can be assessed by testing if the regression estimate of βM in Expression 3 is significantly different from zero using the usual t test. The validity of this test procedure follows from the fact that the marginal effect of X1 in Expression 3 is given by the following expression:4
The moderating effect of X2 on this marginal effect relationship is then given by the derivative of Expression 4 with respect to variable X2:

Hence, as is widely known (e.g., Jaccard, Wan, & Turrisi, 1990), in the standard linear model the estimated coefficient on the interaction variable, defined as the product of the focus and moderator variables, can be used to test for the significance and the nature (i.e., sign) of the underlying hypothesis that the population coefficient on the focus variable varies with the moderator variable.5

While this result follows from the mathematical derivation of the analytically correct moderating effect as given by Expression 5, for the purposes of this article it is important to understand that this result derives more fundamentally from computing the difference in the moderating effect of X2 on the marginal effect of X1 in two models: one that includes the interaction variable and one that excludes the interaction variable. For the linear model considered here, the moderating effect of X2 in the model that includes the interaction variable is, as just derived, βM. For the model that excludes the interaction variable, the marginal effect of X1 is simply β1, and hence in this model the moderating effect of X2 equals zero (i.e., ∂β1/∂X2 = 0). The difference in these moderating effects is (βM – 0) = βM. Hence, testing for significance of βM constitutes a valid test of the substantive moderating hypothesis that the population coefficient on the focus variable varies with the values of the moderator variable not because this coefficient equals the analytically correct moderating effect, but rather because this coefficient equals the difference between the moderating effect in the model that includes the interaction variable and the moderating effect in the model that excludes the interaction variable. This difference in moderating effects is, in the terminology of this article, the secondary moderating effect. This effect measures the incremental contribution of the interaction variable to the moderating effect that exists in the “base” model that excludes the interaction variable. Since βM is the secondary moderating effect for the model given by Expression 3, and since the analytically correct moderating effect for this model also equals βM, the analytically correct moderating effect in this case correctly measures the incremental contribution made to the moderating effect of X2 when the “base” model given by Expression 1 is augmented to include the interaction variable X1X2.

The above strictly linear model is now expanded to allow that each explanatory variable can be a function of its native value. Specifically, let gk[Xk] denote the value of the kth explanatory variable used in the model.6 For example, if gk[Xk] = log[Xk], then the value of variable k used in the model is the logarithm of the native value of Xk. This extension simply allows the standard linear model to be generalized to one that is nonlinear in model variables but linear in model coefficients (e.g., Greene, 2008: 112). This extended form of the linear model can be written:

It is assumed that g0[X0] = 1 so that β0 is the intercept term. For this model, the analogue to introducing interaction variable X1X2 in Expression 1 is to introduce into Expression 6 an interaction variable defined as the product of the functions of the focus and moderator variables, that is, g1[X1]g2[X2]. Given this, the model based on Expression 6 that includes this interaction variable can be written:

This is the usual form in which an interaction variable is introduced in a model. That is, regardless of how the focus and moderator variables are measured (e.g., logarithms, etc.), the interaction variable is computed as the product of the variable values used in the model. For example, if g1[X1] = ln[X1] and g2[X2] = X2, the interaction variable is computed as g1[X1]g2[X2] = ln[X1]X2. Importantly, this method of computing the interaction variable implies the same substantive moderating hypothesis underlying the model given by Expression 3. Specifically, the implied substantive moderating hypothesisis now:

That Expression 8 is the implied substantive moderating hypothesis when the interaction variable is measured as the product of g1[X1] and g2[X2] can be verified by inserting Expression 8 for β1 into Expression 6 to produce exactly Expression 7 (but with β1 in Expression 7 renamed to
β ¯
1
). Importantly, by defining the interaction variable to be the product of g1[X1] and g2[X2], the usual t test for significance of the estimate of βM in the model given by Expression 7 can again be used to test for significance of the substantive moderating hypothesis given by Expression 8. In addition, for the model given by Expression 7, the analytically correct moderating effect of g2[X2] on the relationship between focus variable g1[X1] and the dependent variable again equals βM. In turn, βM again equals the difference between the moderating effect of g2[X2] in the model that includes interaction variable g1[X1]g2[X2] and the moderating effect of g2[X2] in the model that excludes this interaction variable. Hence, in this case, the analytically correct moderating effect again equals the secondary moderating effect. This means the usual t test for significance of the estimate of βM is also a proper test for significance of the contribution that the interaction variable makes to the moderating effect that exists in the model that excludes the interaction variable.

The result that the analytically correct moderating effect equals the coefficient on the interaction variable need not always hold, even in the linear model. For example, for the model given by Expression 6, suppose the moderating effect of interest is how the native value of X2 moderates the relationship between the native value of X1 and the dependent variable. Inserting Expression 8 into Expression 6, the marginal effect of X1 in the resulting model can be written:
Variation in this marginal effect due to variation in the native value of X2 is then:

Unless (∂g1[X1]/∂X1) × (∂g2[X2]/∂X2) = 1, the analytically correct moderating effect given by Expression 10 no longer equals βM; rather, its value is proportional to βM. Since the functions g1[X1] and g2[X2], and hence their derivatives, depend on the values of X1 and X2, Expression 10 is not a constant; rather, its value varies with the values of X1 and X2. Hence, even in the linear model a moderating effect need not be a constant value, and it need not equal the coefficient on the interaction variable in the model.

While in this case the analytically correct moderating effect does not equal the coefficient on the interaction variable, testing for significance of the estimate of this coefficient (i.e., testing βM = 0) remains a proper test for the existence of the substantive moderating hypothesis since Expression 10 is zero when βM = 0, and hence it is also a proper test for the existence of the moderating effect given by Expression 10. This latter result derives from the fact that, in this model, the analytically correct moderating effect given by Expression 10 again equals the secondary moderating effect. That is, Expression 10 equals the difference between two moderating effects: the moderating effect of X2 (not gk[X2]) on the marginal effect of X1 in the model, Expression 7, that includes interaction variable g1[X1]g2[X2] and the moderating effect of X2 in the model, Expression 6, that excludes this interaction variable. In fact, for the class of “linear in model coefficients” models considered in this section, the analytically correct moderating effect will always equal the secondary moderating effect since in such models the moderating effect of the moderator variable in the model that excludes the interaction variable is always zero.

Although equality between the analytically correct moderating effect and the secondary moderating effect means that testing for significance of the estimated coefficient on the interaction variable is also a valid test for the existence of the secondary moderating effect, this does not mean that the sign of this estimated coefficient will also indicate the sign of the secondary moderating effect. For example, the sign of the moderating effect given by Expression 10 depends on the sign of βM and the signs of the derivatives ∂g1[X1]/∂X1 and ∂g2[X2]/∂X2. If the signs of these derivatives are known, then the sign of Expression 10 can be inferred from the sign of βM; that is, the sign of βM is sufficient to identify the sign of this moderating effect. However, if the signs of these derivatives are not known, then the sign of βM alone is not sufficient to identify the sign of this moderating effect. This means that testing for the nature (i.e., sign) of the moderating effect that arises when the substantive moderating hypothesis is true will require computing the values of Expression 10 and assessing their sign and significance.

As will be demonstrated in the next section, the equality between the analytically correct moderating effect and the secondary moderating effect associated with including an interaction variable in a model is no longer assured when an interaction variable is introduced in an LDV model or, more generally, into any model that belongs to the general class of nonlinear models to be considered in the next section. This means that the analytically correct moderating effect may no longer identify the secondary moderating effect and hence no longer identify the moderating effect associated with the substantive moderating hypothesis underlying the introduction of an interaction variable in a model.

sec.title: Structural and Secondary Moderating Effects
sec.p: I now extend the preceding analysis to a more general class of models that allow, as above, that each explanatory variable can be a function of its native value but that also specify that the dependent variable is a nonlinear function of all model variables and their coefficients. The only restriction placed on this more general class of nonlinear models is that the argument of the nonlinear function be a function that is linear in model coefficients. This class of models includes all LDV models commonly used in the management literature. For this class of models, the hypothesized population relationship can be written:

In this expression,
F [

is a nonlinear function whose argument

X k
]
is a function linear in model coefficients.7 Since
F [
Z ¯
]
is nonlinear, this class of models is intrinsically nonlinear, that is, nonlinear in model coefficients and model variables (e.g., Greene, 2008: 285).

Now consider the implications of introducing an interaction variable into the model given by Expression 11. Again, let X1 be the focus variable, let X2 be the moderator variable, and adopt the universal approach of introducing into the model an interaction variable measured as the product of the functions of these two variables (i.e., g1[X1] and g2[X2]). The resulting model can be written:

Note that the function argument in this expression is denoted Z to distinguish it from the argument in Expression 11. While seemingly more complex, the results of the previous section allow us to immediately conclude that introducing the interaction variable into the model given by Expression 11 represents the same substantive moderating hypothesis embedded in Expression 7 and indicated explicitly by Expression 8, namely, that the population coefficient on the focus variable (β1) is a linear and deterministic function of (a function of) moderator variable X2.

The analytically correct moderating effect of moderator variable g2[X2] for the model given by Expression 12 is, as before, given by the cross-partial derivative of Expression 12, first with respect to focus variable g1[X1] and then with respect to moderator variable g2[X2]. The resulting expression can be written:

This expression is a generalization of Expression 2 presented in Ai and Norton (2003). The terms ∂F[Z]/∂Z and ∂2F[Z]/∂Z2 are the first and second derivatives of the nonlinear function F[Z] with respect to its argument Z. The right-hand side of Expression 13 can be rearranged into two components: one that does not directly involve βM and one that is proportional to βM. Performing this rearrangement results in the following expression:8

The fact that the analytically correct moderating effect given by Expression 14 is no longer proportional to βM means that this moderating effect does not identify the secondary moderating effect that arises from the substantive moderating hypothesis of a linear relationship between the moderator variable and the population coefficient on the focus variable. This means that testing for significance of the analytically correct moderating effect is not a proper test for significance of the secondary moderating effect and hence not a proper test for the nature of the contribution of the substantive moderating hypothesis to the moderating effect that exists when this substantive moderating hypothesis is false. What is needed is a method to identify the secondary moderating effect and to then test for the significance of this effect. Toward that end, I now propose a method to decompose the analytically correct moderating effect into its structural and secondary components.

Since the analytically correct moderating effect embeds two component effects, I henceforth call the analytically correct moderating the total moderating effect. Given this, I define the structural moderating effect to be the effect that arises when the substantive moderating hypothesis is false (i.e., when βM = 0). Setting βM = 0 everywhere it appears on the right-hand side of Expression 14 results in the following expression:

Note that in this expression the second derivative

. Given this, I define the secondary moderating effect to be the difference between the total moderating effect and the structural moderating effect. Subtracting Expression 15 from Expression 14, the expression for the secondary moderating effect is:

The secondary moderating effect is the difference between two moderating effects: the moderating effect in the model that includes the interaction variable and the moderating effect in the model that excludes the interaction variable. Since the secondary moderating effect is zero when βM = 0,9 testing for significance of the estimated coefficient on the interaction variable is a proper test of the substantive moderating hypothesis of a linear and deterministic relationship between the moderating variable and the population coefficient on the focus variable and hence also a proper test for significance (i.e., existence) of the secondary moderating effect. However, similar to Expression 10, the value of the secondary moderating effect given by Expression 16 is not a constant, but instead, its value varies with the values of all model variables. This means the sign of βM is not sufficient to identify the sign of the secondary moderating effect. Instead, given βM Π ≠ 0, the values of the secondary moderating effect and their significance will need to be assessed.

By construction, the total moderating effect given by Expression 14 equals the sum of the structural and secondary moderating effects given by Expressions 15 and 16. This decomposition has two important implications. First, as indicated above, if the substantive hypothesis underlying the introduction of the interaction variable in the model is false (i.e., βM = 0), then the secondary moderating effect will be zero and the total moderating effect will equal the structural moderating effect. Second, if the moderator variable is excluded from the model (so that β2 = 0), then the structural moderating effect is zero and the total moderating effect equals the secondary moderating effect.10 Hence, if the moderator variable is excluded from the model, no decomposition of the total moderating effect is required to identify the secondary moderating effect, and therefore, as in the linear model, one need only assess the values of the total moderating effect and their significance to determine the nature and significance of the secondary moderating effect that arises from including the interaction variable in the model.11

The above indicates that the moderating effect of substantive interest when including an interaction variable in a model is the secondary moderating effect and not the total moderating effect. In particular, when including an interaction variable in a model, the relevant moderating hypothesis concerns the nature and significance of the contribution of the substantive moderating hypothesis of a linear relationship between the moderator variable and the population coefficient on the focus variable to the moderating effect that exists in the absence of this substantive moderating relationship. This means that a moderating hypothesis should not be stated in terms of the total moderating effect since this effect only indicates how the relationship between the focus variable and the dependent variable varies with the values of the moderator variable in the model that includes the interaction variable. Rather, a moderating hypothesis should be stated in terms of the secondary moderating effect, since it is this effect that indicates how the substantive moderating relationship, if valid, alters the value of the moderating effect that exists in the model that excludes the interaction variable. When a moderating hypothesis is stated in terms of the secondary moderating effect, one could accept the hypothesis of, for example, a negative moderating effect even if the total moderating effect in the model that includes the interaction variable is positive, since a negative secondary moderating effect will reduce the value of the (positive) total moderating effect relative to its value in the model that excludes the interaction variable. Hence, when seeking to test a moderating hypothesis by including an interaction variable in a model, the proper focus of analysis is the secondary moderating effect and not the total moderating effect.

Of course, one can still state a moderating hypothesis in terms of the total moderating effect, with the understanding that such a hypothesis will concern the nature and significance of the moderating effect that exists in the model that already includes the interaction variable rather than a hypothesis about the incremental contribution made to an existing moderating effect by including an interaction variable in the model. Problematic is that stating a moderating hypothesis in terms of the total moderating effect means that a failure to reject the null hypothesis, and hence accepting the null hypothesis of no total moderating effect, provides no information on the source of acceptance. In particular, failure to reject the null hypothesis could mean that both the structural and secondary moderating effects are not significant or that these effects offset each other in a way that renders the total moderating effect not significant. This simply restates a major point of this article: A hypothesis stated in terms of the total moderating effect may confound two sources of this moderating effect—a structural moderating effect and a secondary moderating effect.

When stating a hypothesis about the total moderating effect, one can still assess whether the substantive moderating hypothesis underlying the secondary effect is valid by testing for significance of the coefficient on the interaction variable. If the substantive moderating hypothesis is rejected, logic suggests dropping the interaction variable and re-estimating the model and then testing for the nature and significance of the total moderating effect that arises in the model that excludes the interaction variable. However, dropping the interaction variable from the model means that the total moderating effect will equal only the structural moderating effect. As discussed next, relying on the structural moderating effect to support a moderating hypothesis faces a number of issues.

First, testing for a structural moderating effect is only possible if the moderator variable is also included as a model variable (and is significant), since otherwise the structural moderating effect, and hence also the total moderating effect, is zero.12 Second, and more important, since the structural moderating effect involves the product of the direct coefficients on the focus and moderator variables, stating and then testing a moderating hypothesis in terms of the structural moderating effect ignores that every significant model variable has a structural moderating effect on the relationship between the focus variable and dependent variable. This fact places the researcher in the awkward position of having to defend the choice to single out only one variable from among the several variables that moderate the relationship between the focus variable and dependent variable.13 Finally, relying only on the structural moderating effect raises the question of how to interpret a failure to reject the null hypothesis of no structural moderating effect since significance of this effect relates fundamentally to significance of the focus and moderating variables in the model and hence fundamentally to the adequacy of the model specification, including perhaps the adequacy of the particular nonlinear model chosen to represent the underlying data-generating process. For these reasons, stating and testing a moderating hypothesis in terms of the total moderating effect must be approached with caution. In particular, it should only be undertaken using a model that includes an interaction variable and then only if the coefficient on the interaction variable is significant. But since a significant interaction variable is required, this again raises the issue of the confounding of structural and secondary effects. It is therefore recommended that the researcher perform the proposed decomposition of the total moderating effect to gain insight as to the source of the acceptance or rejection of a hypothesis regarding the total moderating effect.

To summarize the discussion of this section, augmenting an existing model by including an interaction variable between a focus and moderator variable fundamentally involves the substantive moderating hypothesis of a linear and deterministic relationship between the moderator variable and the population coefficient on the focus variable.A proper test of this substantive moderating hypothesis is to test for significance of the estimated coefficient on the interaction variable in the model. No hypothesis about the sign of this coefficient is needed since only the existence of this substantive moderating relationship is needed to proceed. If the coefficient on the interaction variable is significant, then the sign and significance of the values of the secondary moderating effect can be assessed to determine if the existence of the substantive moderating relationship supports a hypothesis that this relationship will result in a positive (or negative) contribution to the moderating effect that exists in the absence of this substantive moderating relationship.14 While not recommended, if one instead states the moderating hypothesis in terms of the total moderating effect, then the estimated model must include an interaction variable and this variable must show significance in the model. Given this, a hypothesis about the nature of the total moderating effect can then be assessed by testing for the sign and significance of the values of the total moderating effect.15 However, stating a hypothesis in terms of the total moderating effect still raises the question of the relative contribution of the values of the structural and secondary moderating effects to the values of the total moderating effect. Performing the decomposition proposed in this article and examining the values of the associated structural and secondary moderating effects can help provide an answer to this question.

sec.title: The Binary Logit Model
sec.p: This section applies the concepts of the preceding section to the case of the binary logit model to explore the general nature of the total, structural, and secondary moderating effects that can arise in this model. Following this general analysis, a numerical example is presented to illustrate the computation of each moderating effect and methods of interpretation.
For an observation i, a binary logit model that relates the probability of a dependent outcome Yi to a set of (K + 1) explanatory variables Xi = (Xi0, Xi1, . . . , XiK) can be written,

In this expression, Yi is a binary 0/1 dependent variable, β = (β0, β1, . . . , βK) is the (K + 1) vector of model coefficients, and it is assumed that X0 = 1. As stated,
Π
​
[
Z ¯
i
]
is the probability that Yi = 1 (a “success”) for given values of the model variables. In what follows, the observation subscript “i” is dropped since it is not material to the discussion.

Now introduce into the above model an interaction variable defined as the product of focus variable X1 and moderator variable X2. As discussed in previous sections, introducing this interaction variable in the model involves the substantive moderating hypothesis that
β 1

β ¯
1

β M
X 2
. The logit model that includes the interaction variable X1 X2 can be written:

Linking this model to the general results of the preceding section, Π[Z] is the nonlinear function F[Z] from which the total moderating effect given by Expression 14 was derived. Hence, the total moderating effect in this model can be derived by calculating the relevant derivatives of Π[Z] and inserting these into Expression 14. Doing this, the expression for the total moderating effect in a binary logit model can be written:
I now examine for the general properties of the structural and secondary moderating effects associated with this total moderating effect.16

sec.title: Structural Moderating Effect
sec.p: The structural moderating effect is found by setting βM = 0 everywhere it appears in Expression 19. The resulting expression can be written:

In this expression,
Π [

]
is the value of the logit function evaluated at
Z ¯
=

K

. To understand the nature of this structural moderating effect, note first that the bracketed expression that multiplies
β ¯
1
β 2
is the slope of the logistic probability density function (p.d.f.).17 Since the logistic p.d.f. has the familiar bell shape and is symmetric around its mean (when
Z ¯
= 0), Expression 20 is positive for
Π [
Z ¯
]
< 0.5 (the left side of the bell curve), is negative for
Π [
Z ¯
]
> 0.5 (the right side of the bell curve), and is zero when
Π [
Z ¯
]
= 0.5 (the top of the bell curve). Hence, the sign of this structural moderating effect will change over the range of values of the model variables, that is, as the probability
Π [
Z ¯
]
ranges from zero to unity. In particular, if the product of the model coefficients (
β ¯
1
β 2
) is positive, the value of the structural effect will always evolve from being positive to being negative as
Π [
Z ¯
]
goes from zero to unity. Conversely, if the product of the model coefficients (
β ¯
1
β 2
) is negative, the value of the structural effect will always evolve from being negative to being positive as
Π [
Z ¯
]
goes from zero to unity. For
β ¯
1
β 2
≠ 0
, Figure 1 illustrates the two possible relationships, of which one must emerge, for the structural moderating effect in the binary logit model. Since the sign of this structural moderating effect depends only on the sign of the product of the direct coefficients on the focus and moderator variables, observing the signs of the estimated coefficients on these variables is sufficient to indicate the nature of the structural moderating effect in a given logit model. However, the significance of the structural moderating effect values will still need to be assessed.

caption.p: The Two Possible Relationships for the Structural Moderating Effect in a Binary Logit Model

Note: The structural effect value at a given probability value Π is computed using the formula

sec.title: Secondary Moderating Effect
sec.p: The secondary moderating effect is obtained by subtracting Expression 20 from Expression 19. The resulting expression can be written:

In this expression, the function arguments “Z” and “
Z ¯
” are suppressed for expositional clarity, so that Π[Z] and
Π [
Z ¯
]
are now denoted Π and
Π ¯
.18 An examination for the general properties of Expression 21 is complicated by the fact that the predicted probability in the model that includes the interaction variable will in general not equal the predicted probability in the model that excludes the interaction variable (i.e., Π ≠
Π ¯
).19 To make progress, I assume the difference in these two probabilities is “small” and hence that the first term in Expression 21 can be ignored. Given this, Expression 21 can be written more compactly using the fact that in the binary logit model the log-odds or logit value for the model that includes the interaction variable can be written ln
ln [ Π / ( 1 − Π ) ] =
β M
X 1
X 2
∑
k = 0
K
β k
X k
Given this, the term (β1X1 + β2X2 + βMX2X2) in Expression 21 can be written as a residual
R = ln [ Π / ( 1 − Π ) ] − (
β 0
+
∑
k = 3
K
β k
X k
)
. Using this residual expression, and assuming no difference between Π and
Π ¯
, Expression 21 can be written:

Expression 22 indicates succinctly the nature of the (approximate) secondary moderating effect in the binary logit model. Since the residual R can take positive or negative values, determining how the value of this secondary moderating effect varies over the values of Π is less obvious than for the structural moderating effect. Nonetheless, insights are possible.

First, the value of the secondary moderating effect given by Expression 22 equals zero when Π = 0 or Π = 1. In addition, when Π = 0.5, the value of this secondary moderating effect equals βM Π(1 – Π ), whose sign is always the same as the sign of the coefficient on the interaction variable (βM) since Π(1 – Π) is positive. Given this, the important question is whether the value of the secondary moderating effect given by Expression 22 always takes the sign of the coefficient on the interaction variable, or does it instead change sign as the value of Π goes from zero to one? This question is important because, if the sign does not change, then testing for the sign of βM would establish not only the existence of the substantive moderating relationship underlying the use of an interaction variable but would also be a sufficient test for the sign of the secondary moderating effect that arises from this substantive moderating relationship, and hence no analysis of the secondary moderating effect would be required.

To further illustrate the nature of the question and to arrive at an answer, Figure 2 shows different possibilities for the nature of relationship given by Expression 22. Assuming that the coefficient on the interaction variable is positive (i.e., βM > 0), then three values of the relationship given by Expression 22 can be identified: one at Π = 0, one at Π = 1, and one at Π = 0.5. These three values are indicated as solid dots in Figure 2. Given these three known values, the question is then whether the whole relationship given by Expression 22 behaves like Curve A in Figure 2, in which case the sign of the secondary moderating effect is the same as the sign of the coefficient on the interaction variable. Or does it instead behave like Curve B, or like Curve C, or some other relationship such that the value of Expression 22 changes sign as Π goes from zero and one? As suggested by Figure 2, an answer to this question can be found by determining if the relationship crosses the horizontal axis at a value of Π that is strictly between zero and one since, if it does, relationships such as those depicted by Curve A are ruled out.

caption.p: Potential Relationships for the Secondary Moderating Effect in a Binary Logit Model

sec.p: Expression 22 is a complicated expression involving all model variables. To arrive at a partial but not definitive answer to the question posed above, attention can be restricted to the simple model that includes only three variables: X1, X2, and the interaction between X1 and X2. In this case, the residual expression “R” simplifies to R = (ln[Π/(1−Π)] − β0. Using Expression 22, the expression for the secondary moderating effect in this case can be written:

Setting Expression 23 equal to zero, one can solve for the value of Π that makes Expression 23 equal to zero for a given value of β0. If the resulting solution value of Π lies between zero and unity, we can conclude that the values of the secondary moderating effect change sign as Π goes from zero and one. Performing this analysis reveals that a closed-form analytical solution is not possible. However, it can be shown that a close approximation to the solution value (denoted Π*) is given by the following formula:

In general, Expression 24 will produce two solution values for Π*, but only solution values that lie between zero and one are admissible. For example, when β0 = 0, Expression 24 yields two values of Π* that make Expression 23 equal to zero: Π* = 0 and Π* = 6/8 = 0.75. Whereas Π* = 0 is already a known solution, the fact that Π* = 0.75 is also a solution indicates that the values of Expression 23 will undergo a change of sign as Π ranges from zero to unity.20

While not a proof that the value of the secondary moderating effect in the binary logit model will always undergo a change of sign as the value of Π goes from zero to one, the above analysis does suggest that this is likely to be the case. This means that, unlike for the structural moderating effect, the signs of the estimated coefficients on the focus, moderator, and interaction variables do not provide sufficient information to identify the sign of the secondary moderating effect in the binary logit model. Instead, analysis of the secondary moderating effect will require one to compute and assess the significance of its value at each sample observation.

sec.title: Numerical Example
sec.p: This section illustrates the proposed decomposition of the total moderating effect into its structural and secondary components by estimating a simple binary logit model that contains two explanatory variables and an interaction variable formed as the product of these two explanatory variables. The model is estimating using data taken from the example given in Bowen and Wiersema (2004). The data set comprises observations on 199 large public firms that have undergone CEO succession over a specific period of time. The dependent variable, “dismissal,” equals 1 if the CEO was dismissed and zero for routine succession. Since this analysis is simply an illustration, the choice of explanatory variables was based simply on the requirement that they show significance in the estimated model and that the interaction variable formed as the product of their values also show significance in the estimated model. For this example, the following moderating hypothesis is to be tested:

disp-quote.p: Moderating hypothesis: If the population coefficient on focus variable X1 varies linearly with moderator variable X2, then the moderating effect of X2 on the relationship between X1 and the probability of CEO dismissal will be larger the greater is the value of X2.

sec.p: This hypothesis states that the secondary moderating effect is expected to be positive; it does not state that the total moderating effect is expected to be positive, nor does it state that the sign of the coefficient on the interaction variable is expected to be positive.21 Given this, Table 1 shows the results from estimating this simple binary logit model using Stata’s logit command.

caption.p: Logit Results Predicting Probability of CEO Dismissal

fn.p: Note: N = 199.

sec.p: Since the direct coefficients on X1 and X2 are of opposite sign, we can immediately infer that the estimated structural moderating effect in this model will evolve from being negative to positive as the predicted probability of CEO dismissal rises. That the coefficient on the interaction variable is significantly different from zero supports the substantive moderating hypothesis of a linear relationship between variable X2 and the population coefficient on variable X1. This means we can proceed to test our hypothesis of a positive secondary moderating effect. To do so, we need to compute the values of the secondary moderating effect and test for their significance.

Since there are 199 observations, there are 199 values of the total, structural, and secondary moderating effects as given by Expressions 19, 20, and 21. As recent articles have indicated (e.g., Ai & Norton, 2003, Huang & Shields, 2000; Wiersema & Bowen, 2009), one method for analyzing the values of a moderating effect that arise in the logit model is to compute the value and standard error of the effect at each observation22 and to then plot the values of this effect along with their z statistic values, or the upper and lower limits of a 95% confidence interval for each value, against the values of the predicted probability. The resulting graph can then be examined to quickly assess the sign and significance of the values of the moderating effect over the range of variation of the model variables (i.e., the predicted probability that Y = 1).

Based on the estimation results presented in Table 1, Figures 3, 4, and 5 present plots of the computed values of the total, structural, and secondary moderating effects against the values of the predicted probability of CEO dismissal.23 In each figure, the vertical bars attached to a given value indicate the upper and lower limits of the 95% confidence interval for that value. If a bar overlaps the horizontal axis, it indicates that the associated moderating effect value is not significantly different from zero.

caption.p: Total Moderating Effect: Estimated Values and 95% Confidence Intervals
Note: The total moderating effect value at each sample observation was calculated using text Expression 19. The probability of CEO dismissal was predicted using the estimation results in Table 1.
Structural Moderating Effect: Estimated Values and 95% Confidence Intervals

Note: The structural moderating effect value at each sample observation was calculated using text Expression 20. The probability of CEO dismissal was predicted using the estimation results in Table 1 but with the interaction variable excluded.
Secondary Moderating Effect: Estimated Values and 95% Confidence Intervals

Note: The secondary moderating effect value at each sample observation was calculated using text Expression 21. The probability of CEO dismissal was predicted using the estimation results in Table 1 but with the interaction variable excluded.

sec.p: Figure 3 shows that the value of the total moderating effect is positive and significant when the probability of CEO dismissal is between about 0.48 and 0.65, is negative and significant when the probability of CEO dismissal is less than about 0.10, and is otherwise not significant. Figure 4 shows that the values of the structural moderating effect follow, as expected, a horizontal S-shaped relationship, with the values evolving from negative to positive as the predicted probability of CEO dismissal rises. However, the value the structural moderating is significant only when the predicted probability of CEO dismissal is less than 0.2 or greater than 0.8. Hence, the structural moderating is generally not significant for most values of the predicted probability of CEO dismissal.

Figure 5 indicates that values of the secondary moderating effect follow the expected horizontal S-shape relationship with the values evolving from positive to negative as the predicted probability of CEO dismissal rises. As seen in Figure 5, the value of the secondary moderating effect is consistently positive and significant when the probability of CEO dismissal is between about 0.10 and 0.5 and is otherwise not significant. Since the coefficient on the interaction variable is significant (Table 1), these results support the hypothesis of a positive secondary moderating effect. Hence, the existence of a linear relationship between the moderator variable and the population coefficient on the focus variable increases the value of the total moderating effect relative to its value in the absence of this linear relationship. It can be remarked that if the moderator and focus variables were meaningful constructs and not simply “generic” variables, the finding that the secondary moderating effect is positive and significant only over a certain range of values of the predicted probability of CEO dismissal may in fact have a substantive interpretation.

If the moderating hypothesis in this example were instead stated in terms of a positive total moderating effect then, as shown in Figure 3, this hypothesis would be supported only for values of the probability of CEO dismissal between about 0.48 and 0.68. The behavior of the values of the total moderating effect can be understood by comparing the values of the structural and secondary moderating effects in Figures 4 and 5 at different values of the probability of CEO dismissal. In this regard, it can be seen that the sign of the structural moderating effect is generally opposite the sign of secondary moderating effect at any given probability value, and in fact these relationships are almost mirror images.24 Hence, these two effects mostly cancel out, rendering the total moderating effect not significantly different from zero. However, as the probability of CEO dismissal rises above about 0.5, the structural effect becomes positive and the secondary effect becomes negative, with the positive values of the structural moderating effect generally exceeding the negative values of the secondary moderating effect so that the total moderating effect becomes positive (and significant). However, important is that since the values of the secondary moderating effect are negative, these positive values of the total moderating effect derive only from the positive values of the structural moderating effect. Hence, it would be incorrect, as is commonly done, to infer that the positive and significant total moderating effect derives from including the interaction variable in the model. This analysis illustrates that inferences based on values of the total moderating effect can be misleading, and it underscores that it is the secondary moderating effect and not the total moderating effect that should be used to test for the nature of the moderating effect that arises when including an interaction variable in a model.

The example presented above used one graphical technique to examine for the value and significance of the moderating effects that arise in nonlinear models such as the logit. Another technique is that recently discussed by Zelner (2009), but it should be remarked that his analysis is undertaken only with respect to the total moderating effect, and it therefore needs to be modified to examine only the secondary moderating effect. But, regardless of the method used, assessing the validity of a moderating hypothesis in a nonlinear model will require a good deal of post-estimation analysis. As Wiersema and Bowen (2009) remarked, it is unlikely that the type of graphical analyses done for the numerical example presented above would be allowed to appear in a published article, largely due to a constraint on the number of pages. Hence, while it is recommended that the researcher undertake the type of graphical analysis presented here, all that needs to be reported are the conclusions from this analysis and not the full graphical displays.

In this regard, a commonly used summary procedure is to test for significance of the value of the moderating effect computed at the sample means of the explanatory variables. Clearly, this computation can be undertaken for the structural and secondary effects as well as the total moderating effect. For the binary logit model, testing for the significance of each moderating effect at the variable means would seem to have an advantage since, as indicated earlier, the structural moderating effect in this model is zero at the mean of logistic distribution (i.e., when Π = 0.5), and hence at the mean of this distribution the total moderating effects equals the secondary moderating effect. This suggests that testing for the significance of the total moderating effect computed at the variable means would then also constitute a test for the significance of the secondary moderating effect. However, for this procedure to be valid, the predicted probability computed at the variable means must equal the mean of the predicted probabilities (i.e., the mean of the estimated logit cumulative distribution function). In fact, this requirement will only be met for the binary logit model if the proportion of observations for which Y = 1 equals one half (Lien, 1986). In the data underlying the numerical example presented above, the sample proportion of observations for which Y = 1 is 0.38. Hence, all three moderating effects at the variable means must be computed to test for the nature and significance of these effects.

Computing the value of each moderating effect at the variable means25 gives the following results (with standard error and p value in parentheses): total moderating effect: 0.901 (0.532, p = .09); structural moderating effect: –0.268 (0.667, p = .688); secondary moderating effect: 1.169 (0.327, p = .000). Whereas the total and structural moderating effects at the variable means are not significant at the 5% level, the secondary moderating effect is positive and significant at the 1% level, supporting the hypothesis of a positive secondary moderating effect.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Researchers frequently postulate and test that the relationship between one explanatory variable (the focus variable) and the dependent variable is moderated by another variable (the moderator variable) by including in a model an interaction variable measured as the product of the values of the focus and moderator variables. This article has demonstrated that the fundamental basis for including an interaction variable in a model is the substantive moderating hypothesis of a linear and deterministic relationship between the moderator variable and the population coefficient on the focus variable, and that a proper test of this substantive moderating hypothesis is to test for the significance of the estimated coefficient on the interaction variable in the model. While this test procedure is a well-known result in the case of the standard linear model, recent articles (e.g., Ai & Norton, 2003) have questioned the validity of this practice in the case of nonlinear LDV models such as the logit, since the analytically correct or total moderating effect in such models does not equal this coefficient, and have therefore argued that to test a moderating hypothesis in such models one must assess the value and significance of the total moderating effect. Contrary to this assertion, this article demonstrated that for a general class of nonlinear models that includes all LDV models commonly used in the management literature, testing for significance of the coefficient on the interaction variable is a valid test for the significance (i.e., existence) of the substantive moderating hypothesis that gives rise to including an interaction variable in a model, and that a proper test for the nature of the moderating effect that arises when this substantive moderating hypothesis is valid is to test for the sign and significance of the values of the secondary moderating effect, not the total moderating effect. This analysis emphasized that when seeking to test a moderating hypothesis by including an interaction variable in a model, the correct conceptualization of a moderating hypothesis is in terms of the contribution that the interaction variable will make to the moderating effect that exists in the model that excludes the interaction variable. That is, there is a fundamental difference between hypothesizing the nature of the moderating effect that will exist in a model that includes an interaction variable and hypothesizing the nature of the contribution that adding an interaction variable to a model will make to an already existing moderating effect. What this means is that, when seeking to test a moderating hypothesis by including an interaction variable in a model, the moderating effect of substantive interest is always what this article has labeled the secondary moderating effect.

Since it is the secondary moderating effect that is of substantive interest when testing a moderating hypothesis by including an interaction variable in a model, this article proposed a method to decompose the total moderating effect that arises in any nonlinear model that includes an interaction variable into its two component effects: the structural moderating effect that derives from the inherent nonlinearity of the model and the secondary moderating effect that arises from including the interaction variable in the model. This decomposition allows the researcher to identify and test for significance of the secondary moderating effect, and it also allows for an understanding of how the values of these two components contribute to the value of the total moderating effect. A key implication of this decomposition is that the total moderating effect equals the secondary moderating effect if the moderator variable is not a model variable. Hence, prior studies that have used as a moderating variable a variable that is excluded from the model, and that have tested their moderating hypothesis by examining for the significance of the total moderating effect, have in fact identified the secondary moderating effect and have therefore conducted a proper test of their moderating hypothesis.

The proposed decomposition was applied to the case of the binary logit model to examine theoretically for the nature of the moderating effects that will arise when an interaction variable is included in this model. It was shown that the values of the structural moderating effect will evolve predictably as the probability of the dependent outcome evolves from zero to one, and that the nature of this evolution depends only on the signs of the estimated direct coefficients on the focus and moderator variables. In contrast, the values of the secondary moderating effect are not immediately predictable, but analysis suggested that the values of the secondary moderating effect are likely to follow an S-shaped pattern around the horizontal axis, with the sign of the secondary moderating effect changing from positive to negative, or from negative to positive, as the probability of the dependent outcome evolves from zero to one.

A numerical example using the binary logit model confirmed the theoretical expectations regarding of the behavior of the values of the structural and secondary moderating effects in this model. This analysis highlighted that the values of the secondary moderating effect can differ markedly from those of the total moderating effect, and hence the different inferences that would be drawn about the moderating effect that arises when including an interaction variable in a model. The example also illustrated how insight into the nature the total moderating effect can be gained by examining the behavior of the values of its structural and secondary components and their significance.

This article contributes to a growing body of literature that, given the increasing use of LDV models in management research, has sought to inform researchers of the proper methods for analyzing and interpreting the results from such models (e.g., Ai & Norton, 2003, Bowen & Wiersema, 2004; Hoetker, 2007; Wiersema & Bowen, 2009). In demonstrating that the moderating effect that arises when including an interaction variable in a model can have both a structural and a secondary component, and that assessing the nature and significance of the values of the secondary component is the proper method for assessing a hypothesis concerning the moderating effect that will arise from including an interaction variable in any model, it is hoped that researchers will have a greater understanding of how to state and interpret a moderating hypothesis in LDV and other inherently nonlinear models and can thereby sharpen, and have greater confidence in, the inferences drawn when using such models.

app.title: Appendix A
app.p: The following Stata commands compute, at each sample observation, the value of the total, structural, and secondary moderating effects in a binary logit model. The value of each effect, and the 95% confidence interval for each value, is then graphed as in Figures 3, 4, and 5. Finally, the value and significance of each effect at variable means is computed and reported. The terms X1, X2, and X12 below denote the model variables X1, X2 and X1X2.

app.title: Appendix B
app.p: This appendix presents general formulas for the total, structural, and secondary moderating effects when the focus and moderator variables are variously continuous or discrete 0/1 variables. Each case assumes moderator variable X2 is included in the model. If X2 is instead excluded from the model then the structural effect is zero, and the secondary effect is found by setting β2 = 0 in the formula for the total effect.

p.bold: Case 1: X1 is a continuous variable; X 2 is a discrete 0/1 variable
Case 2: X1 is a discrete 0/1 variable; X 2 is a continuous variable
Case 3: Both X 1 and X 2 are discrete 0/1 variables

app.p: Note that if ∂F/∂Z > 0 (i.e., F is a strictly increasing function of its argument Z) then Z > Z* implies (F[Z] – F[Z*]) > 0. From Expression 33, this means the secondary effect is positive when βM > 0 and is negative when βM < 0. Hence, like Puhani (2008), when X1 and X2 are both 0/1 variables the sign of the coefficient on the interaction variable (βM) is sufficient to identify the sign of the secondary moderating effect. However, significance of the sign of Expression 33 must still be assessed. In none of the other cases considered in Appendix B is the sign of the coefficient on the interaction variable sufficient to identify the sign of the secondary moderating effect.

ack.p: This article was accepted under the editorship of Talya N. Bauer. I gratefully acknowledge the comments of Michael Leiblein and three anonymous reviewers during the preparation of this article. An earlier version, titled “Testing for Moderating Effects in Limited Dependent Variable Models: Structural Versus Secondary Interactions,” was presented at the 2008 Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management, Research Methods Division.

fn.p: As explained later in this article, the analytically correct moderating effect is the cross-partial derivative (or cross-difference) of the conditional expectation of a model’s dependent variable, first with respect to a “focus” explanatory variable and then with respect to the moderator variable.

For example, Feinberg and Gupta (2009) explore their direct hypotheses by estimating a tobit (limited dependent variable) model but explore their moderating hypotheses by estimating a linear regression model in order to “avoid the issues raised by Ai and Norton (2003) concerning interpreting interactions in nonlinear models” (p. 393).
See Appendix B for extension to the cases where each variable is either discrete or continuous.

The validity of this test procedure is also directly evident from Expression 2 since βM = 0 implies that β1 is a constant value independent of moderator variable X2. However, most analyses rarely make explicit the substantive moderating hypothesis given by Expression 2 and instead justify this test procedure by showing analytically that the moderating effect of X2 on the marginal effect of X1 in the model given in Expression 3 equals βM.

Since ∂Y/∂X1∂X2 = ∂Y/∂X2∂X1 = βM it is often suggested (e.g., Zelner, 2009) that the moderating effect associated with an interaction variable is symmetric; that is, the role of moderator and focus variable are interchangeable. Explicitly stating the moderating hypothesis as done in Expression 2 denies this claim of symmetry; symmetry is a mathematical artifact, not a hypothesis. However, when the moderating variable is included as a model variable (see note 11), the use of an interaction variable can involve an identification problem. If, in addition to the hypothesis given by Expression 2, one adds the hypothesis that
β 2
=
β ¯
2
+
λ M
X 1
,
then the implied model is
∂ M
= Y (
β M

λ M
)

+
β ¯

β ¯

+
∑
k = 3
k
β k
X k
.
Estimating this model yields an estimate of δM = (βM + λM) and not individual estimates of βM and λM. This identification problem means that significance of the estimate of δM is consistent with one or both moderating hypotheses being valid. This issue is not further addressed in this article. Instead, this article assumes that outside information indicates that λM = 0, and hence that an estimate of δM is an estimate of βM alone.
For expositional clarity, a function is denoted using square brackets rather than parentheses, that is, gk[Xk] instead of gk(Xk).
It is assumed that g0[X0] = 1.
For variation in the native values of the focus and moderator variables the expression analogous to Expression 14 is:

If βM = 0 in Expression 16, then
Z =
Z ¯
,
, and hence
(
∂ 2
F [

] / ∂
Z 2
−
∂ 2
F [
Z ¯
] / ∂

2
) = 0 .
.

In Expression 15, the second derivative
∂ 2
F [
Z ¯
] / ∂
Z ¯
2
measures the degree of “curvature,” or nonlinearity, of the model relationship given by Expression 12. Hence, the closer is
∂ 2
F [
Z ¯
] / ∂
Z ¯
2
to zero, the more linear is the model relationship over the range of values of the model variables, and the smaller is the structural moderating effect, and hence the closer will be the total moderating effect to equaling the secondary moderating effect.

This has implications for the conventional wisdom (e.g., Aiken & West, 1991) that both variables defining an interaction variable should be included separately in a model that includes the interaction variable. While the focus variable must always be a model variable (else there is no relationship between this variable and dependent variable to moderate), including also the moderator variable if previously excluded on theoretical grounds will, for the class of nonlinear models considered here, prevent identifying the secondary moderating effect directly from the total moderating effect (it can also introduce an identification problem; see note 5). Hence, a moderating variable should not be included in a model unless there is a theoretical basis for its inclusion.

However, if the model initially excludes the moderator variable on theoretical grounds then including this variable in the model permits testing for a structural moderating effect with respect to this variable. In this case, testing significance of the total moderating effect correctly tests the null hypothesis of no (structural) moderating effect against the alternative hypothesis of a (structural) moderating effect with respect to the moderator variable.
See Berry, DeMeritt, and Esarey (2010) for further discussion of this issue.

That the secondary moderating effect correctly captures the substantive moderating hypothesis explains the conclusion of Puhani (2008), who rejects the claim of Ai and Norton (2003) that the sign of the coefficient on the interaction variable is not sufficient to identify the sign of the moderating effect in a classic difference-in-differences (DID) model (in this model, X1 and X 2 are discrete 0/1 variables). In the DID model, the hypothesis of interest concerns the difference between the expected value of the outcome variable for the group that receives treatment and the expected value of the outcome variable when this group does not receive treatment, where the comparison in outcome values is made between two time periods (i.e., before and after treatment). As shown in Appendix B, the “moderating” effect Puhani derives for testing this hypothesis is exactly the secondary moderating effect as defined in this article when X1 and X 2 are discrete 0/1 variables—for example, compare Puhani’s Expression 10* to Expression 33 in Appendix B).

One should not confuse the process of stating and testing a hypothesis regarding the expected nature of a total moderating effect with an analysis that simply examines ex post the estimated values of this effect and their significance.

For the logit model, the issue of structural and secondary moderating effects does not arise when the dependent variable is the proportion of successes rather than discrete 0/1 data. Proportions data allow use of the log-linear logit model that linearly relates the log odds of the dependent outcome to the model variables. Since the model is linear, the total moderating effect equals the secondary moderating effect and hence the methods of stating and testing a moderating hypothesis in this model are identical to that for the standard linear model.
That is, Π[Z](1 − Π[Z])(1 − 2Π[Z]) = d2Π[Z]/dZ2 where Π[Z] is the logistic cumulative distribution function.
However, it should not be forgotten that this probability is a function of all model variables and their coefficients.

They are equal only if
Z =
Z ¯
,
.
Numerical simulations of Expression 24 reveal that, regardless the value of β0, at least one of the solution values derived from Expression 24 will be a value of Π* between zero and one.

However, one could state such a hypothesis. If so, it would be tested by testing for significance of the sign of the coefficient on the interaction variable using the usual t test. But the sign of this coefficient does not indicate the sign of the secondary moderating effect unless the focus and moderator variables are both discrete 0/1 variables (see Note 14 and the discussion following Case 3 in Appendix B).

The standard error at each observation is normally computed using the delta method (e.g., see Greene, 2008: 68). Zelner (2009) presents an alternative method for deriving the standard error based on simulation.

To enable direct comparison, the predicted probability values along the horizontal axis in Figures 4 and 5 are computed using the coefficient estimates in Table 1 but with the coefficient on the interaction variable set equal to zero.
This was also true when additional explanatory variables where added to the model.
This computation uses the sample mean of the interaction variable and not the product of the sample means of the focus and moderating variables.
